title: Upgrade Guide
description: Learn how to upgrade to the latest Nuxt version.

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: To use the latest Nuxt build and test features before their release, read about the
Nuxt 4 is planned to be released
(though obviously this is dependent on having enough time after Nitro's major release to be properly tested in the community, so be aware that this is not an exact date).
Until then, it is possible to test many of Nuxt 4's breaking changes from Nuxt version 3.12 or via the nightly release channel.
Watch a video from Alexander Lichter showing how to opt in to Nuxt 4's breaking changes already.
First, opt in to the nightly release channel

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: // To re-enable _all_ Nuxt v3 behavior, set the following options:

, defaults throughout your Nuxt configuration will change to opt in to Nuxt v4 behavior, but you can granularly re-enable Nuxt v3 behavior when testing, following the commented out lines above. Please file issues if so, so that we can address them in Nuxt or in the ecosystem.
Breaking or significant changes will be noted here along with migration steps for backward/forward compatibility.
This section is subject to change until the final release, so please check back here regularly if you are testing Nuxt 4 using
Nuxt now defaults to a new directory structure, with backwards compatibility (so if Nuxt detects you are using the old structure, such as with a top-level
directory, this new structure will not apply).
by default, and most things are resolved from there.
is added, which is the directory we look for

children.value: // This reverts the new srcDir default from `app` back to your root directory
// This specifies the directory prefix for `app/router.options.ts` and `app/spa-loading-template.html`
We enabled a previously experimental feature to share data from
between pages that are prerendered. This can result in a significant performance improvement when prerendering sites that use
and fetch the same data in different pages.
For example, if your site requires a

call for every page (for example, to get navigation data for a menu, or site settings from a CMS), this data would only be fetched once when prerendering the first page that uses it, and then cached for use when prerendering other pages.
Make sure that any unique key of your data is always resolvable to the same data. For example, if you are using
to fetch data related to a particular page, you should provide a key that uniquely matches that data. (
should do this automatically for you.)

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: // This would be unsafe in a dynamic page (e.g. `[slug].vue`) because the route slug makes a difference
// to the data fetched, but Nuxt can't know that because it's not reflected in the key.
// Instead, you should use a key that uniquely identifies the data fetched.
Alternatively, you can disable this feature with:

children.value: between pages that are prerendered. This can result in a significant performance improvement when prerendering sites that use
and fetch the same data in different pages.
It is particularly important when enabling this feature to make sure that any unique key of your data is always resolvable to the same data. For example, if you are using
to fetch data related to a particular page, you should provide a key that uniquely matches that data. (
should do this automatically for you.)
// This would be unsafe in a dynamic page (e.g. `[slug].vue`) because the route slug makes a difference
// to the data fetched, but Nuxt can't know that because it's not reflected in the key.
// Instead, you should use a key that uniquely identifies the data fetched.
. This change is to bring greater consistency.

Provides access to data that resolves asynchronously in an SSR-friendly composable.
See
An asynchronous function that must return a truthy value (for example, it should not be
) or the request may be duplicated on the client side.

Force a refresh, even if there is already a pending request. Previous requests will
not be cancelled, but their result will not affect the data/pending state - and any
previously awaited promises will not resolve until this new request resolves.

.
Boolean values will be removed in a future release.
These aliases were removed, for greater clarity.

, and we removed the boolean values as they ended up being
existing requests in favour of this new one'. But passing
means 'do not make any new requests if there is an existing pending request.' (See

When new data is fetched, anything depending on
will still be reactive because the entire object is replaced. But if your code changes a property
that data structure, this will not trigger any reactivity in your app.
performance improvement for deeply nested objects and arrays because Vue does not need to watch every single property/array for modification. In most cases,
In most cases, no migration steps are required, but if you rely on the reactivity of the data object then you have two options:
You can granularly opt in to deep reactivity on a per-composable basis:

+ const { data } = useFetch('/api/test', { deep: true })

hook now emits a path which is absolute rather than relative to your project

, and offers better support for layers and other more complex patterns.

children.value: to compile templates located on the file system using the
In addition, we provided some template utilities (
) which could be used for code-generation within these templates, which are now being removed.
In Nuxt v3 we moved to a 'virtual' syntax with a
function which is much more flexible and performant.

has had a succession of security issues. These do not really apply to Nuxt projects because it is being used at build-time, not runtime, and by trusted code. However, they still appear in security audits. Moreover,
is a hefty dependency and is unused by most projects.
Finally, providing code serialization functions directly within Nuxt is not ideal. Instead, we maintain projects like
which can be dependencies of your project, and where security issues can be reported/resolved directly without requiring an upgrade of Nuxt itself.
We have raised PRs to update modules using EJS syntax, but if you need to do this yourself, you have three backwards/forwards-compatible alternatives:
Moving your string interpolation logic directly into
Using a custom function to handle the replacement, such as in

children.value: Four experimental features are no longer configurable in Nuxt 4:
These options have been set to their current values for some time and we do not have a reason to believe that they need to remain configurable.
In the table below, there is a quick comparison between 3 versions of Nuxt:
The migration guide provides a step-by-step comparison of Nuxt 2 features to Nuxt 3 features and guidance to adapt your current application.
guide to migrating from Nuxt 2 to Nuxt 3

If you prefer to progressively migrate your Nuxt 2 application to Nuxt 3, you can use Nuxt Bridge. Nuxt Bridge is a compatibility layer that allows you to use Nuxt 3 features in Nuxt 2 with an opt-in mechanism.
Migrate from Nuxt 2 to Nuxt Bridge
